{{Multiple issues|{{more citations needed|date=August 2015}}{{cleanup reorganize|date=June 2015}} {{Orphan|date=August 2015}} {{Underlinked|date=September 2018}}}} [[File:Sports Federation of India logo.jpg|thumb|Monogram of Sports Federation of India]] The '''Sports Federation of India''' (SFI) is an [[autonomous entity]] registered under Trust Act 1950 (INDIA), aspiring to promote professionalism in sports and establishment of quality standards in educational organizations preferably in rural and semi-urban regions of [[India]]. == Objectives == [1] The objectives for which the Trust is founded are: # To work for promotion of Professional Sports and incidentally sport persons, Primary and higher education in the fields of literature and arts, culture, science, commerce, law, B.Ed., Fine Arts, Medical, Para Medical, Pharma, Engineering, Management, housing, Architecture and various allied educational/ Technical courses, across all sections of society also using sport persons. Trust shall be a public charitable trust having no profit motives. # # To work in alliance and support of the government agencies in implementing the policies made by the central and/or state governments for the purpose of facilitating professional sports training, housing, education and food and/or other fundamental needs also using sport persons. # # To work for promotion of Professional Sporting, education etc. by the said Trust having charitable character, setout herein after as it is necessary, for the fulfillment of the desire of the “author” and to which may be added such other objects from time to time as is necessary for the benefits of the trust. # # To establish Professional Sports training Schools/ Academies, Educational and Research institutions of all stature, Old Age Homes, Short Stay Homes for benefits of public without any distinction also using sport persons. # # To also work and focus on Professional Sports training, Development of Sports Multiplexes / Stadiums / Schools, and Primary, Secondary, Higher, Technical, Medical, Paramedical, Pharmaceutical, Engineering, Management, Architecture and/or other various allied educational institutions to aid players and the wards of former players of any stature across India. # # To work for the social, economical, educational, professional, physical (Health), mental i.e. an all round development for the under privileged section of society taking professional aptitude for sports the centre of overall activities. # # To promote better understanding and harmony among various regional, linguistic and religious groups through sport’s # # To promote, train and hone boys and girls professionally in the field of sports, technology, education, medical and all possible fields and provides quality content and teaching aid. # # To provide training of foreign languages to needy sport persons and under trainees # # To use information technology to its full extent for propagation of information and knowledge. # # To organize events for promotion of sports, sports trainees, technology, culture, arts, fashion, industrial training and others when and where required for social benefits in collaboration with corporate world under Corporate Social Responsibilities. # # To grant scholarship to deserving candidates/students/sports persons # # To aid self entrepreneurship by providing economic support, training and management support also using sport persons. # # To establish Institutions for the benefit of society like Hospital, Dispensaries, Nursing Homes, Asylums, Orphanage, Dharamshalas / Musafir Khana, Inns etc. also using sport persons. # # To liaison and develop mutual areas of co-operation with different organization of national regional and international stature as well as with specialized institutions and individuals to further the objectives of the federation also using sport persons. # # To assist the national and international funding agencies in bilateral and mutual development of institutions in alleviating poverty and augmenting human development also using sport persons. # # To organize seminars, workshops, conferences in all the priority areas mentioned above. # # To collaborate and co-operate with the institutions and organizations having similar aims and objectives. # # To carry on such further charitable objects of general public utility as are compatible or in conscience with the objectives of the trust. # # To work in alliance with government and non government agencies to eradicate social evils like illiteracy, poverty, superstition and other factors that re card the general development of the humanitarian traits, irrespective of race, sex, colour, religion, cast and creed also using sports etc. # # To preserve and develop specialized areas to represent vintage heritage of Indian societies, i.e. develop vintage cities depicting the cultures of different iconic civilization of India to promote tourism. # # To establish research institution to aid and promote invention, discoveries, development of arts, culture, literature and other aspects of research for betterment of mankind for betterment of sports and the people in need. # # To establish centers to provide subsidized medical aid in compliance with national, international, government and non government agencies to sport persons and the people in need. # # To establish universities or deemed universities promoting sports # # To publish journals, news papers, books for promotion of knowledge, sports and to exchange ideas and promote art, literature and ideologies. # # To lend money from Trust Fund or provide other resources from the trust property to deserving candidature duly decided by the trustees, for fulfillment of either or all of the objectives of the trust. # == Proposed Project Model == 1 In tandem with the prime objective of defining sports as a viable career option, the Federation started establishing sports academies. In the meantime, it was realized that the timing of formal schools and coaching classes incorporated with the lack of resources are the major stumbling blocks. It is to this context in reaching the desirous goal of promoting professional sports amongst children. Considering the assessed scenario, a social model of development for sustainable growth is being proposed (model- 1) by the federation. SFI is ready to take a lead through opening Schools and thus imparting quality standards and professional sports training thereon. So far, three schools and one sports academy in rural India have already been set up and the training of around 1000 student is been done. Considering the socio-economic profile of targeted populace the facilities are kept almost free, in turn causing severe fund crisis to run the existing institutions and replicating a new one. == At a Glance == === Areas of intervention === # Adventure Sports # Professional Sports # Health & Fitness # Education === Activities === ==== Adventure Sports ==== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Activities !! Adults !! Children |- | Peak climbing || "yes" || X |- | Trekking || "yes" || "yes" |- | Nature Safari || "yes" || "yes" |} ==== Professional Sports ==== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Activities !! Corporate !! Professional !! School Children |- |Tournaments || "yes" || "yes"|| "yes" |- |Summer Camp || X || "yes" || "yes" |- |Winter Camp || X || "yes" || "yes" |- |Training Camps || X || "yes" || "yes" |- |Sports Carnival || X || "yes" || "yes" |- |Self Defense Training || "yes" || "yes" || "yes" |} === Institutions Developed/Associated === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Sports !! Education !! Health & Fitness |- |City Sports Club, Amroha || Unity Public School, Hussainabad, Jharkhand || Yoga Club |- |R.S Cricket academy, Gajraula || H.H Girls Junior Highschool, Basti || Pangot revival point, Nainital |- |Haldwani Sporting, Haldwani || MAHM International School, Vatranasi || Gym and Health Club |- | || Sports School, Almora (Proposed) || |} === Health & Fitness === # Yoga Camp # Rejuvenation Spot # Health Clubs === Education === {{Quote box |quote = Organize different camps and provide an opportunity to have a tryst with the nature and a respite from the cacophony of everyday life at rejuvenation spots, there is a network of affiliated health clubs whose services are offered to frequent travelers.
Engage in helping others with federation's expertise in establishing educational institutions of different nature. Proposals are solicited, to open new schools from interested individuals / organizations who feel the need of such institutions in different regions of India. |width = 30% |align = right }} ==== Endeavors ==== # Setting up Schools # Setting up Sport Schools # Setting up Sport Academies ==== Activities ==== # Educational Tours # Cultural Events # Training & Workshops # Student Exchange Programs # Skill Development Programs == Concerns == The federation anyhow manages the affiliates so far by organizing different events related to adventure sporting, professional sporting, events of cultural significance as well as voluntary contributions. The federation has successfully established organizations i.e. Schools and sports academies, but in respect of the level of demand it is just a start and there is much potential envisage to take it to the larger scale. It is to this context to benefit those incumbents who are far behind in approaching such facilities. Otherwise they would be denied of making their dream come true. Considering the demand for affordable schools and sports facilities in rural and semi-urban areas where there is limited access to quality education and sports opportunities. It is ensured that the students in these institutions get sufficient opportunity to assess their talents and pursue them. Sports academies are run in conjunction with schools for professional training right from the very beginning. Apart from sports and education, developing other talents in the students is also among the concerns of the organization. Training and education of around 1000 student is being done in the institutions developed so far. Basis on above mentioned scenario following are the major concern emerges for the organization === # Quality Education === To maintain and run a sustainable development scheme or project, quality checks and assessments are found to be mandatory. Sustainability is solely dependent on the quality of output a system provides. Quality of education and training provided in the institutions run under or in association with the trust is vital, and has become the prime concern of the organization to achieve its goals. === # Professional Sports Training === Spots have been a successful career for many, but still there is a negative general perception of sports being a career. This may be because of lack of professional sports training in rural and under developed areas. Census 2011 has documented that the total population that lives in rural India, is 83.3 cr. that is 70% of the total Indian population. Further there are regions in urban India that has not yet been developed to its full extent and are termed semi urban regions. These underdeveloped regions do also host a large population. Such a vast scope of opportunity placed professional sports training amongst the prime concerns of the trust undisputedly. === # Fund raising === Expansion of the objectives of trust solely depends upon the procurement of fund. The trust anyhow managed the pilot projects by different means. For expansion and maximization of the reach of federation fund raising has proved to be a big challenge. === # Professional Skill Development === === # Network Building and Knowledge Sharing === In pursuit of achieving its goals the federation found that sport trainers and educators often work individually and could not utilize their full potential. Due to lack of awareness regarding available opportunities and procedures many talents can’t find their way to success. This analysis gave way to the need of building support base network to help trainers, educators and trainees to move out to new places. This is to use the skills of trainers and educators to train potential talents on one hand and showcase the polished talents on the other. == References == {{Reflist}} http://trustsfi.com/ http://trustsfi.com/education/ http://trustsfi.com/sports/ http://trustsfi.com/adventure/ SFI Profile [[Category:Sport in India]]

'''''The Concierge Questionnaire''''' is an online travel magazine, launched in 2009, featuring locals with “travel answers from those who know," and inspired by the [[Proust Questionnaire]].
Since April 2011, [[Chantal Westerman]], former Entertainment Editor and Hollywood Correspondent of ABC's [[Good Morning America]] (GMA), has been hosting ''ConciergeQ Conversations with Chantal Westerman.'' ''ConciergeQ Conversations with Chantal Westerman'' are in-depth interviews with guests who are also featured on ''The Concierge Questionnaire.'' Ms. Westerman's first featured guests were [[Fort Worth Opera]] and [[The Thrilling Adventure Hour]].
The Concierge Questionnaire launched URHereTravel, focusing on event and festival coverage, in March 2012. The launch included the first video interview of ''ConciergeQ Conversations with Chantal Westerman.'' Ms. Westerman's guest was filmmaker Heather Rae - 2008 [[Independent Spirit Award]] Producer of the Year.
Maria Prekeges hosts ConciergeQ's URHereTravel food, wine and spirits coverage. Her celebrity interviews have included [[Brent Ridge]] and [[Josh Kilmer-Purcell]] of [[The Fabulous Beekman Boys]], and Chef John Tesar of [[Top Chef (season 10)]].
Frequent contributors to ''The Concierge Questionnaire'' include: [[Richard Bangs]] and [[Mary Ann Davidson]].

{{Infobox film | name = The Lone Ranger | image = TheLoneRanger2013Poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | alt = A man with his face painted white and a black bird on his head, beside a man in a black mask and white cowboy hat. | director = [[Gore Verbinski]] | producer = {{plainlist| *[[Jerry Bruckheimer]] *Gore Verbinski }} | screenplay = {{plainlist| *[[Justin Haythe]] *[[Ted Elliott (screenwriter)|Ted Elliott]] *[[Terry Rossio]] }} | story = {{plainlist| *Ted Elliott *Terry Rossio *Justin Haythe }} | based on = {{Based on|''[[Lone Ranger]]''|{{unbulleted list|[[Fran Striker]]
[[George W. Trendle]]}}}} | starring = {{Plain list | *[[Johnny Depp]] *[[Armie Hammer]] *[[Tom Wilkinson]] *[[William Fichtner]] *[[Barry Pepper]] *[[James Badge Dale]] *[[Helena Bonham Carter]] }} | music = [[Hans Zimmer]] | cinematography = [[Bojan Bazelli]] | editing = {{plainlist| *[[James Haygood]] *[[Craig Wood (film editor)|Craig Wood]] }} | studio = {{plainlist| *[[Walt Disney Pictures]] *[[Jerry Bruckheimer|Jerry Bruckheimer Films]] *[[Infinitum Nihil]] *[[Gore Verbinski|Blind Wink Productions]]}} | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Walt Disney Studios
Motion Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2013|6|22|[[Hyperion Theatre]]|2013|7|3|United States}} | runtime = 149 minutes{{cite web|title=The Lone Ranger|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/lone-ranger-2013|publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|accessdate=June 11, 2013}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $225–250 million{{cite news|last=Graser|first=Marc|title=Disney, Bruckheimer See ‘Lone Ranger’ as New Genre-Bending Superhero|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/disney-bruckheimer-see-lone-ranger-as-new-genre-bending-superhero-1200501501/|accessdate=June 26, 2013|newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=June 25, 2013|quote=The picture cost approximately $250 million to produce, and more than $150 million to market and distribute around the globe ... Pre-production was halted until the filmmakers could wrangle the cost down to a more manageable $215 million ... Despite all the strife over the budget, the ultimate cost of “The Lone Ranger” ballooned during production. Bruckheimer says he and Disney were responsible for covering the film’s overages. Studio reps say the pic cost around $225 million, but sources say it was considerably higher.}} | gross = $260.5 million{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=loneranger.htm |title=The Lone Ranger (2013) |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=August 18, 2013}} }} '''''The Lone Ranger''''' is a 2013 American [[Western (genre)|western]] [[action film]] directed by [[Gore Verbinski]] and written by [[Justin Haythe]], [[Ted Elliott (screenwriter)|Ted Elliott]] and [[Terry Rossio]]. Based on the radio series [[Lone Ranger|of the same name]], the film stars [[Johnny Depp]] as [[Tonto]], the narrator of the events and [[Armie Hammer]] as John Reid, the Lone Ranger. The film is told through Tonto's memories of the duo's earliest efforts to subdue local villainy and bring justice to the [[American frontier|American Old West]]. [[William Fichtner]], [[Barry Pepper]], [[Ruth Wilson]], [[James Badge Dale]], [[Tom Wilkinson]] and [[Helena Bonham Carter]] also are featured in supporting roles. It is the first theatrical film featuring the [[Lone Ranger]] and Tonto characters in the more than 32 years following [[William A. Fraker]]'s 1981 film, ''[[The Legend of the Lone Ranger]]''.{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Ted|title=1981 ‘Lone Ranger’ Pic Galloped Quickly Into Oblivion|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/1981-lone-ranger-pic-galloped-quickly-into-oblivion-1200501507/|accessdate=June 26, 2013|newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=June 25, 2013}} Produced by [[Walt Disney Pictures]], [[Jerry Bruckheimer|Jerry Bruckheimer Films]] and Depp's [[Infinitum Nihil]], filming was plagued with production problems and budgetary concerns which at one point led to the film's premature cancellation. The film was released theatrically in the United States on July 3, 2013 and was a [[box office bomb]], grossing only $260.5 million worldwide against an estimated $225–250 million production budget and an additional $150 million in marketing costs. The film received two [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nominations for [[Academy Award for Best Visual Effects|Best Visual Effects]] and [[Academy Award for Best Makeup and Hairstyling|Best Makeup and Hairstyling]].{{cite news|last1=Bacle|first1=Ariana|title='The Lone Ranger' joins list of movies nominated for both Razzies and Oscars|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2014/01/16/the-lone-ranger-razzies-oscars|accessdate=May 18, 2015|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=January 18, 2014}} ==Plot== In 1933, a boy named Will who idolizes the legendary [[Lone Ranger]] encounters the elderly [[Comanche]] [[Tonto]] in a [[sideshow]] at a [[San Francisco]] fair. Tonto [[frame story|proceeds to recount]] his experiences with that [[Old West]] adventurer. In 1869, lawyer John Reid returns home to Colby, [[Texas]], via the uncompleted [[First Transcontinental Railroad|Transcontinental Railroad]], managed by railroad tycoon Latham Cole. Unknown to Reid, the train is also carrying Tonto and outlaw Butch Cavendish, who is being transported for his [[hanging]] after being captured by Dan Reid, John's [[Texas Ranger Division|Texas Ranger]] brother. Cavendish's gang rescues Butch and derails the train. Tonto is subsequently jailed. Dan deputizes John as a Texas Ranger, and with six others they go after the Cavendish gang. Cavendish's men ambush and kill their pursuers. Cavendish slays Dan with his [[dagger]] and [[Cannibalism|devours his heart]] as revenge for his imprisonment. Tonto, who has escaped from jail, comes across the dead men and buries them. However, a white [[spirit]] [[horse]] awakens John as a "spirit walker", and Tonto explains John cannot be killed in battle. Tonto also tells him Collins, one of the Rangers, betrayed Dan and is working with Cavendish. As John is thought to be dead, he wears a mask to protect his identity from enemies. Tonto gives John a silver [[bullet]] made from the fallen Rangers' badges and tells him to use it on Cavendish, whom he believes to be a mystical beast called a [[wendigo]]. At a [[brothel]] Collins recently visited, Red Harrington informs the two about Dan and Collins' fight over a cursed silver rock. Meanwhile, Cavendish's men, disguised as Comanches, raid frontier settlements. John and Tonto arrive after raiders abduct Dan's widow and son, Rebecca and Danny. Regretting his earlier actions, Collins attempts to help the mother and child escape, but is shot dead by Cole, who rescues them. Claiming the raiders are hostile Comanches, Cole announces the continued construction of the railroad and dispatches [[United States Cavalry|US Cavalry]] Captain Jay Fuller to [[Genocide|wipe out the Comanches]]. A Comanche tribe captures John and Tonto after the pair finds railroad tracks in Native territory. The leader tells John of Tonto's past: As a boy, Tonto had rescued Cavendish and another man from near-death and later showed them a [[mountain]] full of [[silver]] ore in exchange for a [[pocket watch]]. The men murdered the tribe to keep the location a secret, leaving Tonto with great guilt which led to him believing the two were wendigos. Tonto and John escape as the cavalry attack the Comanche. At the silver mine, the duo captures Cavendish. Tonto demands John use the silver bullet to kill Cavendish, but John refuses. Upon returning Cavendish to Cole and Fuller's custody, Cole is revealed to be Cavendish's partner and brother. Fuller, fearful of being labeled a [[war criminal]] for slaughtering the tribe, sides with Cole. Rebecca is held hostage, and John is returned to the mine to be executed. Tonto rescues him and the two flee. Realizing Cole is too powerful to be taken down lawfully and regretful since his arrogance in ignoring Tonto led to the mass slaughter of the Comanches and the kidnapping of his loved ones, John dons the mask again. At [[Promontory, Utah|Promontory Summit]], during the railroad's [[golden spike|union ceremony]], Cole reveals his true plan: to take control of the railroad company and use the mined silver to gain more power. John and Tonto steal [[nitroglycerin]] and use it to destroy a railroad bridge. With Red's help, Tonto steals the train with the silver, and Cole, Cavendish and Fuller pursue him in a second train on which Rebecca and Dan Jr. are being held captive. On horseback, John pursues both trains. After a furious chase and fights on both trains, Cavendish and Fuller are killed, Rebecca and Dan Jr. are rescued, and Cole drowns while being buried beneath the silver ore after the train plunges off the severed bridge and into the river below, killing him. The town recognize John as a hero and offers him a law-enforcement position. John declines, and he and Tonto ride off. Back in 1933, Will questions the truth of the story. Tonto gives him a silver bullet and tells him to decide for himself, and then departs. ==Cast== {{multiple image | direction = vertical | footer = Johnny Depp and Armie Hammer at the film's premiere at [[Disneyland]] | image1 = Johnny Depp, The Lone Ranger premiere at Disneyland, 2013.jpg | width1 = 150 | image2 = Armie Hammer, The Lone Ranger premiere at Disneyland, 2013.jpg | width2 = 150 }} *[[Armie Hammer]] as [[Lone Ranger|John Reid/Lone Ranger]], a youthful, scrupulous lawyer later deputized a [[Texas Ranger Division|Texas Ranger]], who protects his identity as the "Lone Ranger", a masked vigilante who seeks the perpetrators responsible for his brother's death.{{cite news|last=Wright|first=Celine|title='The Lone Ranger' premiere: A long red carpet under a hot sun|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-lone-ranger-20130623,0,3597587.story|accessdate=26 June 2013|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date =June 3, 2013}} *[[Johnny Depp]] as [[Tonto]], the aged narrator of the events of his life as a Comanche who recruited John Reid to bring justice to those responsible for massacring his tribe during his childhood, and terrorizing frontier Texas settlements during the 1800s. The character wears black-and-white face paint and a deceased crow on his head.{{cite news|last=Fonseca|first=Felicia|title=Disney's Tonto Offensive To Some In Upcoming 'Lone Ranger' Film|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/12/disney-tonto-offensive-lone-ranger-film_n_3263071.html|accessdate=August 31, 2013|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=May 12, 2013}} According to Depp, the inspiration for the costume was a painting entitled ''I Am Crow'' by Kirby Sattler.{{cite news|last=Breznican|first=Anthony|title=Johnny Depp reveals origins of Tonto makeup from 'The Lone Ranger'|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2012/04/22/johnny-depp-reveals-origins-of-tonto-makeup-from-lone-ranger-exclusive/|accessdate=February 16, 2013|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=April 22, 2012}} Joseph E. Foy portrays Tonto as a child. *[[William Fichtner]] as Butch Cavendish, a ruthless and cannibalistic outlaw, who Tonto believes is a [[wendigo]].{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=87364|title=''The Lone Ranger'' Lassos William Fichtner|accessdate=February 23, 2012 | publisher=ComingSoon.net|date=February 22, 2012}} Travis Hammer portrays the younger Butch seen in flashbacks. *[[Tom Wilkinson]] as Latham Cole, a burly and unscrupulous railroad tycoon.{{cite news|last=Graser|first=Marc|title=Tom Wilkinson circles ‘Lone Ranger’|url=https://variety.com/2011/film/news/tom-wilkinson-circles-lone-ranger-1118038967/ |accessdate=June 26, 2013 |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=22 June 2013}} Steve Corona portrays the younger Cole seen in flashbacks. *[[Ruth Wilson]] as Rebecca Reid, Dan's wife (later widow) and John's love interest/sister-in-law. *[[Helena Bonham Carter]] as Red Harrington, an ivory-legged [[brothel]] madam who assists Reid and Tonto. *[[James Badge Dale]] as Dan Reid, John's older brother who is killed by Cavendish.{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/james-badge-dale-shame-flight-rubicon-lone-ranger-interview/136359|title=James Badge Dale Talks SHAME, Director Steve McQueen, Robert Zemeckis’ 'Flight', 'Rubicon', 'The Lone Ranger', and a Lot More|accessdate=February 23, 2012|publisher=Collider.com|date=January 20, 2012|first=Steve|last=Weintraub}} *Bryant Prince as Danny Reid, Rebecca and Dan's son, John's nephew. *[[Barry Pepper]] as Captain Jay Fuller, an insecure and inexperienced [[United States Cavalry]] officer. *[[Mason Cook]] as Will, a young boy living in 1930s San Francisco.{{cite news|last=Rome|first=Emily|title=On the scene at 'The Lone Ranger' premiere; Plus, if the film were a Disney theme park ride|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/06/23/the-lone-ranger-premiere-california-adventure/|accessdate=26 June 2013|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=June 23, 2013}} *[[Saginaw Grant]] as Chief Big Bear, leader of the Comanche.{{cite news|last=Scott|first=A.O.|title=Hero Rides Again, With Big Boots to Fill|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2013/07/03/movies/in-the-lone-ranger-tonto-takes-center-stage.html?_r=0|accessdate=July 4, 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 2, 2013}} *[[Harry Treadaway]] as Frank, a member of Butch's gang who enjoys women's clothing. *[[Lew Temple]] as Hollis, a Deputy Ranger.{{cite news|last=Ross|first=Dalton|title=Lew Temple (a.k.a. Axel) talks about the latest 'Walking Dead' shocker — Exclusive|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/02/17/walking-dead-lew-temple-axel/2/|accessdate= July 3, 2013|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date= February 17, 2013|page=2}} *[[Leon Rippy]] as Collins, a traitorous Deputy Ranger secretly working with Butch. *[[Stephen Root]] as Habberman, president of the Transcontinental Railroad Company. *[[James Frain]] as Barret, one of Cole's industry foremen.{{cite news|last=Kit|first=Borys|title='True Blood' Actor Joins 'Lone Ranger' | url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/true-blood-lone-ranger-james-frain-274750|accessdate=June 26, 2013|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=16 December 2011}} *[[Damon Herriman]] as Ray, a member of Butch's gang. ==Production== ===Development=== In March 2002, [[Columbia Pictures]] announced their intention to make a ''Lone Ranger'' film with [[Classic Media]], who owned the film rights at the time. Husband and wife producers [[Douglas Wick]] and Lucy Fisher joined the project. The tone was to be similar to ''[[The Mask of Zorro]]'', and Columbia suggested that [[Tonto]] be re-written as a female love interest. The projected budget was set at $70 million.{{cite news|first = Claude|last= Brodesser | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117861889 | title = ''Ranger'' rides to Columbia | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date = 2002-03-05 | accessdate = 2008-10-31}} [[David Peoples|David]] and [[Janet Peoples]] were hired to write the script the following year,{{cite news|first = Dana |last=Harris | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117885874 | title = Col, Wagon rope Peoples for ''Lone'' | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date = 2003-03-08 | accessdate = 2008-10-31}} which was rewritten by [[Laeta Kalogridis]]. [[Jonathan Mostow]] was attached to direct by early 2005,{{cite news|first = Jill |last=Goldsmith | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117915937 | title = Finding gold in Classic fare | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date = 2005-01-09 | accessdate = 2008-10-31}} but Columbia placed the film in [[turnaround (filmmaking)|turnaround]]. [[The Weinstein Company]] was interested in purchasing the film rights from Classic Media in 2007{{cite news|first = Steven |last=Zeitchik | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117956872 | title = Weinsteins keen on kids | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date = 2007-01-07 | accessdate = 2008-10-31}} but the deal fell apart when [[Entertainment Rights]] eventually optioned the property. They teamed with producer [[Jerry Bruckheimer]] and brought ''The Lone Ranger'' to [[Walt Disney Pictures]]. [[Ted Elliott (screenwriter)|Ted Elliott]] and [[Terry Rossio]], who worked with Bruckheimer and Disney on the [[Pirates of the Caribbean (film series)|''Pirates of the Caribbean'' film series]], were being courted to write the script.{{cite news|first = Peter|last= Gilstrap | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117965303 | title = ''Pirates'' scribes ride wave of success | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date = 2007-05-18 | accessdate = 2008-10-31}} In late March 2008, Elliott and Rossio were in final negotiations.{{cite news|first = Borys |last=Kit|first2= Carl|last2= DiOrio | title = Disney preps ''Lone Ranger'' remake | work = [[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date = 2008-03-27 }} Disney then announced in September 2008 that [[Johnny Depp]] would be portraying Tonto{{cite news | first = Jenna | last = Cooper | url = http://movieblog.ugo.com/index.php/movieblog/more/disney_announces_upcoming_films_tron_prince_of_persia_and_the_lone_ranger_s | title = Disney Announces Upcoming Films, 'Tron,' 'Prince of Persia', and the 'Lone Ranger' Starring Johnny Depp | publisher = [[UGO Networks]] | date = September 25, 2008 | accessdate = 2008-10-31 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090126125409/http://movieblog.ugo.com/index.php/movieblog/more/disney_announces_upcoming_films_tron_prince_of_persia_and_the_lone_ranger_s/ | archivedate = January 26, 2009 | deadurl = yes | df = }} while the Elliot-Rossio script was rewritten by [[Justin Haythe]].{{cite news|first=Jim |last=Vejvoda|url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/106/1068935p1.html|title=Lone Ranger's Revolutionary Writer|work=[[IGN]]|date=2009-02-12|accessdate=2010-10-22}} The Elliot and Rossio script reportedly had a [[supernatural]] plot element involving [[coyote]]s. In May 2009, [[Mike Newell (director)|Mike Newell]], who was then directing ''[[Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (film)|Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time]]'' for Bruckheimer and Disney, entered negotiations to direct ''Lone Ranger''.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8028788.stm|work=[[BBC Online]]|date=May 1, 2009|title=Newell 'in talks for Lone Ranger'|accessdate=2009-05-02}} Bruckheimer explained the following June that he wanted to wait before hiring a director, until Newell completed ''Prince of Persia,'' and until Depp finished filming ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides]].'' "The priority is most definitely ''Pirates 4,"'' Bruckheimer commented. "They are going to cast the title role once they get a director and Disney greenlights. We don't have a director yet."{{cite news|first=Edward |last=Douglas|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=56211|work=ComingSoon.net|date=June 11, 2009|title=Bruckheimer Gives Updates on Pirates & The Lone Ranger|accessdate=2009-06-16}} In September of 2010, [[Gore Verbinski]] was hired to direct. Verbinski had suggested giving the role of Tonto to Depp while filming the [[Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest|second ''Pirates of the Caribbean'']] film.{{cite news|last=Ford|first=Rebecca|title=CinemaCon: 'Lone Ranger' Filmmakers on Making a Western That Works|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cinemacon-lone-ranger-filmmakers-making-441502|accessdate=April 19, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=April 17, 2013}} Filming was slated to begin after Depp finished work on ''[[Dark Shadows (film)|Dark Shadows]]''.{{cite news|first=Michael |last=Fleming|url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/09/gore-verbinski-in-talks-to-reteam-with-johnny-depp-on-lone-ranger|title=Gore Verbinski In Talks To Reteam With Johnny Depp On 'Lone Ranger'|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=September 27, 2010|accessdate=2010-10-22}} Actor [[Armie Hammer]] was selected to play the Lone Ranger, a role that Bruckheimer described as being written for "a young [[James Stewart|Jimmy Stewart]] character".{{cite news|last=Graser|first=Marc|title=Johnny Depp, Armie Hammer Unveil ‘The Lone Ranger’ at California Adventure|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/johnny-depp-armie-hammer-unveil-the-lone-ranger-at-disneyland-1200501597/|accessdate=26 June 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=June 24, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/archives/armie_hammer_eyeing_the_lone_ranger_with_johnny_depp |title=Armie Hammer Eyeing 'The Lone Ranger' With Johnny Depp | publisher=[[IndieWire]] |date=April 27, 2011 |first=Kevin |last=Jagernauth |accessdate=June 2, 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2011/film/news/armie-hammer-to-play-the-lone-ranger-1118037227/ | title = Armie Hammer to play the Lone Ranger | work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |first=Marc |last=Graser | first2=Justin | last2=Kroll | date=May 17, 2011| accessdate=June 10, 2013}} ====Setback==== {{quote box|width=30%|align=right|quote="When you're spending other people's money, you want to give them back a return on their investment. Every time you go out there, you have to swing for the fences."|source=—Jerry Bruckheimer, on the subject of the film's budget}} On August 12, 2011, Disney announced that production on ''The Lone Ranger'' would be delayed due to budget concerns expressed by CEO [[Bob Iger]] and then [[Walt Disney Studios (division)|Walt Disney Studios]] chairman [[Rich Ross]].{{cite journal |url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/08/13/disney-halts-johnny-depp-lone-ranger |title=Disney halts Johnny Depp's 'Lone Ranger' |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=August 13, 2011 |first=Dave |last=Karger |accessdate=June 2, 2013}} The studio and production team constrained the film's allocated budget, with Verbinski, Bruckheimer, Depp, and Hammer, equally deferring 20% of their salaries to minimize the overall cost. After addressing the project's production problems in October 2011, Disney confirmed that the film was back on track after the budget was reworked to give the studio a chance to recoup its costs. Initially, filming was reported to begin on February 6, 2012, for a projected release date of May 31, 2013,{{cite news|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/10/the-lone-ranger-saddling-up-with-johnny-depp-and-a-tighter-budget|title=‘The Lone Ranger’ Sets February 6 Start Date; Giddyap!|last=Flemming|first=Mike|date=October 12, 2011|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=11 November 2011}} which subsequently was moved to the [[Independence Day (United States)|Fourth of July]] weekend of that same year. After [[Alan F. Horn]] replaced Rich Ross as chairman of the Walt Disney Studios in 2012, he began working right away on the film, and insisted on trimming most of the scene where Cavendish eats Dan Reid's heart. Horn later explained: "I like heart in my movies ... but not that much heart."{{cite news|last1=Rainey|first1=James|title=Disney’s Alan Horn Uses Low-Key Approach, Keen Creative Vision to Find Hits of the Future|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/alan-horn-disney-chairman-1201749971/|accessdate=14 December 2016|work=Variety|publisher=Variety Media|date=11 April 2016|location=Los Angeles}} ===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] began on March 8, 2012, and, soon after, the first photograph of Depp as Tonto and Hammer as the Lone Ranger was released.{{cite web|url=http://www.superherohype.com/news/articles/169811-first-look-at-johnny-depp-and-armie-hammer-in-the-lone-ranger |title=First Look at Johnny Depp and Armie Hammer in The Lone Ranger! |work=Superhero Hype |date=March 8, 2012 |accessdate=June 2, 2013}} Filming locations extended throughout six states: [[Utah]], [[Colorado]], [[New Mexico]], [[Arizona]], Texas, and California. Some filming occurred specifically near [[Creede, Colorado]], in June 2012;{{cite web|url=http://www.filmincolorado.com/lone_ranger.html|title=Disney Feature Spends 3 Weeks - $7M in Creede, CO|work=Film in Colorado|date=9 July 2012|access-date=2013-04-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130709112116/http://www.filmincolorado.com/lone_ranger.html#|archive-date=2013-07-09|dead-url=yes|df=}} [[Moab, Utah]], in July 2012; and [[Cimarron Canyon State Park]], New Mexico in August.{{cite web|url=http://ratonrange.com/lone-ranger-rides-into-area-movie-filming-in-cimarron-canyon-state-park-an-p3757-1.htm|title=Lone Ranger rides into area; Movie filming in Cimarron Canyon State Park and Angel Fire region|accessdate=30 August 2012|work=The Raton Range|first=Todd|last=Wildermuth|date=21 August 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224112723/http://ratonrange.com/lone-ranger-rides-into-area-movie-filming-in-cimarron-canyon-state-park-an-p3757-1.htm#|archive-date=2013-12-24|dead-url=yes|df=}} Second unit ([[stunt]] and [[Chroma key|blue screen]]) work commenced in late September 2012 in the parking lot of Santa Anita Racetrack, Arcadia, California.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} The film was shot in the [[anamorphic format]], with cinematographer [[Bojan Bazelli]] using [[Panavision]] [[Anamorphic format#Origination|C- and G-Series]] lenses.{{cite web|title=Watch the Official Trailer for "The Lone Ranger" |url=http://www.panavision.com/spotlight/watch-official-trailer-lone-ranger |work=[[Panavision]] |date=October 3, 2012 |accessdate=October 29, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Blair| first=Iain| title=The Masked Man |url=http://www.hdvideopro.com/display/features/the-masked-man.html| work=HDVideoPro.com |date=July 2, 2013 |accessdate=July 9, 2013}} Daytime exteriors—about 70 percent of the film—were shot on [[Eastman Kodak|Kodak]] [[Vision3|VISION3 50D 5203]] [[35 mm film]] with Panavision [[Panavision cameras#Panaflex Platinum|Panaflex Platinum]] and [[Arriflex 435]] cameras; interiors and nighttime exteriors were shot [[digital cinematography|digitally]] with [[Arri Alexa]] [[Arri Alexa#Alexa Studio|Studio]] cameras. The shoot met with several problems including inclement weather, [[wildfire]]s, a [[chickenpox]] outbreak and the death of crew member Michael Andrew Bridger on September 21, 2012.{{cite news|title='Lone Ranger' Crew Member Drowns On Set|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-19692147|publisher=BBC|accessdate=23 September 2012|date=23 September 2012}}{{cite news|last=Kit|first=Borys|title='Lone Ranger' Crewmember Dies on Set|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/lone-ranger-crewmember-dies-set-372991|accessdate=13 June 2013|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=21 September 2012}} Bridger, a water safety expert, died while working inside a large water tank.{{cite web|url=http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/388930/20120928/investigation-launched-johnny-depp-film-set-lone.htm#.UeISKxysIgg|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121001054000/http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/388930/20120928/investigation-launched-johnny-depp-film-set-lone.htm#.UeISKxysIgg|dead-url=yes|archive-date=1 October 2012|title=Investigation Launched At Johnny Depp’s Film Set Of ‘The Lone Ranger’ After A Crew Member Died [PHOTOS] - Entertainment & Stars|publisher=Au.ibtimes.com|date=|accessdate=20 July 2013}} Several cast members had to receive formal training on [[Equestrianism|horseback riding]], [[Gunfighter|gunslinging]], and [[lasso]]ing.{{cite news|last=Ford|first=Rebecca|title='Lone Ranger' Premiere Brings Johnny Depp, Armie Hammer and the Wild West to Disneyland|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/lone-ranger-premiere-johnny-depp-573813|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=23 June 2013}} [[Industrial Light & Magic]] created the visual effects for ''The Lone Ranger'',{{cite news|last=Cohen|first=David|title=Industrial Light & Magic Ups John Knoll to Chief Creative Officer|url=https://variety.com/2013/digital/news/industrial-light-magic-ups-john-knoll-to-chief-creative-officer-exclusive-1200484450/|accessdate=1 June 2013|newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=23 May 2013}} including a CGI-rendering of the [[Golden Gate Bridge]] as it looked while under construction during 1936 - although the film's opening is set in 1933.{{cite news|last=McCarthy|first=Todd|title=The Lone Ranger: Film Review|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/lone-ranger-film-review-577558/|accessdate=21 November 2017|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=30 June 2013}} Beginning in November 2013, the [[Autry National Center]] exhibited the costumes Hammer and Depp wore in the film through a loan from the Walt Disney Archives.{{cite web|title=The Autry Announces The Lone Ranger Costume Loan From the Walt Disney Archives, a Significant Addition to Its Display of Western Film Artifacts and Memorabilia|url=http://theautry.org/press/the-autry-announces-the-lone-ranger-costume-loan-from-the-walt-disney-archives|publisher=Autry National Center|access-date=2013-11-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224020817/http://theautry.org/press/the-autry-announces-the-lone-ranger-costume-loan-from-the-walt-disney-archives#|archive-date=2013-12-24|dead-url=yes|df=}} ===Music=== {{main|The Lone Ranger (soundtrack)}} In April 2012, it was announced that [[Jack White]] was hired to compose the score for the film.{{cite news|title=Jack White to Compose Score for Johnny Depp's 'The Lone Ranger'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jack-white-the-long-ranger-johnny-depp-317489|accessdate=22 April 2013|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=27 April 2012}} White later declined to work on the film's music, citing scheduling conflicts, and he was replaced with [[Hans Zimmer]] in December 2012.{{cite news|last=Stutz|first=Colin|title=Hans Zimmer Replaces Jack White as 'Lone Ranger' Composer|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/earshot/hans-zimmer-replaces-jack-white-composer-lone-ranger-402843|accessdate=22 April 2013|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=14 December 2012}} In March 2013, [[Michael Einziger]] tweeted that he was working with Zimmer on the score.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/MichaelEinziger/status/313897980736450560|title=Working with Hans Zimmer on the score for The Lone Ranger!|publisher=Twitter|accessdate=19 March 2013}} The film's soundtrack was issued by [[Walt Disney Records]] in two releases: Zimmer's film score and the "inspired by" [[concept album]] on July 2, 2013.{{cite web|title=Walt Disney Records to Release Soundtracks for ‘The Lone Ranger’ and ‘Monsters University’|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2013/03/20/walt-disney-records-to-release-soundtracks-for-the-lone-ranger-and-monsters-university/|publisher=Film Music Reporter|accessdate=22 April 2013|date=20 March 2013}}{{cite news|last=Cubarrubia|first=R.J.|title=Grace Potter and the Nocturnals Board the 'Devil's Train' - Song Premiere|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/grace-potter-and-the-nocturnals-board-the-devils-train-song-premiere-20130529|accessdate=29 May 2013|newspaper=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=29 May 2013}} ==Release== As a result of the production setbacks, ''The Lone Ranger'' faced numerous release date changes. [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures]] initially scheduled the film for a mid-2011 release date,{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} but ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides]]'' replaced it because the latter was considered a priority for the studio and that ''The Lone Ranger'' did not have a director.{{cite news|first=Edward|last=Douglas|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=56211|work=ComingSoon.net|date=11 June 2009|title=Bruckheimer Gives Updates on Pirates & The Lone Ranger|accessdate=16 June 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/686Io382H?url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=56211|archivedate=1 June 2012|deadurl=no|df=}} After [[Gore Verbinski]] signed for director, ''The Lone Ranger'''s release date was moved to December 21, 2012. Budget concerns and negotiations resulted in a production delay so the release date was pushed to May 31, 2013.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disneys-lone-ranger-sets-may-31-release-date-248191|title=Official: Disney's 'Lone Ranger' Sets May 31, 2013 Release Date|last=Masters|first=Kim|date=13 October 2012|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=1 June 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/686Irvo1e?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disneys-lone-ranger-sets-may-31-release-date-248191|archivedate=1 June 2012|deadurl=no}} By mid-2012, [[DreamWorks Pictures]]' ''[[Robopocalypse (film)|Robopocalypse]]'' was facing its own production delays and could not meet its July 3, 2013 release date and therefore Disney had ''The Lone Ranger'' assume its place for the [[Fourth of July]] holiday weekend.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-fox-robopocalypse-postpones-release-331811|title=Disney, Fox Postpone Release of 'Robopocalypse' to 2014|last=Kilday|first=Gregg|date=31 May 2012|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=1 June 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/686IwMlfZ?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-fox-robopocalypse-postpones-release-331811|archivedate=1 June 2012|deadurl=no}} The first [[Movie trailer|trailer]] debuted at [[San Diego Comic-Con International|San Diego Comic-Con]] before being released theatrically on October 3, 2012.{{cite news|last=Goldberg|first=Matt|title=Comic-Con: Disney Surprises with First Trailer for THE LONE RANGER|url=http://collider.com/the-lone-ranger-trailer-comic-con/|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=Collider.com}} Television promotions for the film aired during [[Super Bowl XLVII]].{{cite news|last=Warner|first=Denise|title='The Lone Ranger': Watch the new Super Bowl trailer — Video |url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/02/03/the-lone-ranger-trailer-super-bowl/|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=3 February 2013}} Disney used the film's production connection to the ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean (film series)|Pirates of the Caribbean]]'' series as the main [[tagline]] in the film's marketing, as well as featuring the film's two main characters in promotional materials for ''[[Disney Infinity (video game)|Disney Infinity]]''.{{cite news|last=Cheney|first=Alexandra|title=With 'Lone Ranger,' Disney Bets on a Mythic Western Hero|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323998604578563854096237488|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=23 June 2013|quote=In its marketing, Disney is linking "The Lone Ranger" to its blockbuster "Pirates of the Caribbean" franchise. In its digital and on-air campaigns, the studio is using the phrase "from the team that brought you" and inserting the well-known image of a skull outfitted with the red bandana and other accessories of Captain Jack Sparrow, the flamboyant "Pirates" character portrayed by Mr. Depp.}}{{cite news|last=Clark|first=Noelene|title=‘Lone Ranger’ play set coming to ‘Disney Infinity’ video game|url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/games/lone-ranger-play-set-coming-to-disney-infinity-video-game/#/0|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=6 June 2013}} ''The Lone Ranger'' was selected as the closing film for the [[Taormina Film Fest]]ival.{{cite news|last=Lyman|first=Eric|title='The Lone Ranger' to Close Italy’s Taormina Festival|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/lone-ranger-close-taormina-festival-566188|accessdate=13 June 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=11 June 2013}} Its world premiere was held on June 22 at the [[Hyperion Theater]] in the [[Hollywood Land]] district of [[Disney California Adventure]], with proceeds being donated to the [[American Indian College Fund]].{{cite news|last=Kaufman|first=Amy|title=Disney selling tickets to 'Lone Ranger' premiere for $1,000 a pop|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-johnny-depp-lone-ranger-premiere-ticket-buy-20130529,0,5053979.story?track=rss|accessdate=30 May 2013|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=29 May 2013}}{{cite news|last=Salemi|first=Michelle|title=Disney’s ‘The Lone Ranger’ Premiere Tickets Cost a Cool Thousand Bucks|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/disneys-the-lone-ranger-premiere-tickets-cost-a-cool-thousand-bucks-1200489463/|accessdate=30 May 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=29 May 2013}} The film was remastered and released in [[IMAX]] theaters on August 7, 2013 in several international territories including the United Kingdom and Japan.{{cite news|last=Kemp|first=Stuart|title='The Lone Ranger' to Hit U.K. Imax Theaters Two Days Ahead of Local Wide Release|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/lone-ranger-hit-uk-imax-597943|accessdate=7 August 2013|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=1 August 2013}}{{cite news|last=Vlessing|first=Etan|title=Disney’s ‘Lone Ranger’ to Ride Into Imax Theaters Overseas on August 2|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-s-lone-ranger-ride-567504|accessdate=13 June 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=12 June 2013}} ===Home media=== ''The Lone Ranger'' was released by [[Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment]] on [[Blu-ray]] and DVD on December 17, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.cinelinx.com/blu-crew/item/4658-disney-s-the-lone-ranger-coming-to-blu-ray-december-17.html|title=Disney's The Lone Ranger coming to Blu-ray December 17|date=September 20, 2013|publisher=Cinelinx|accessdate=2013-09-20}} It was released in Australia on October 31.{{cite web|url=http://www.jbhifionline.com.au/dvd/dvd-genres/action-adventure/lone-ranger-the/689626|title=Lone Ranger, The|website=www.jbhifionline.com.au}} ==Reception== ===Box office=== The film grossed $89,302,115 in the United States and $171,200,000 in other countries for a worldwide total of $260,502,115. Preliminary reports had the film tracking for a $60–$70 million debut in North America.{{cite news|last=Oldham|first=Stuart|title=Box Office: ‘Lone Ranger’ Feeling Despicable on Fourth of July|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/box-office-lone-ranger-feeling-despicable-on-fourth-of-july-1200523061/#article-comments|accessdate= July 5, 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=5 July 2013}} The film earned $2 million from late showings on Tuesday, July 2, 2013 and $9.67 million on its opening day, July 4.{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Box Office Report: 'Despicable Me 2' Leaves 'Lone Ranger' in the Dust|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-report-despicable-me-6|accessdate= July 7, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date= July 3, 2013}} During its opening weekend, the film debuted in second place with $29.3 million over three days and $48.9 million over the five-day frame.{{cite news|last=Mendelson|first=Scott|title=Weekend Box Office: 'The Lone Ranger' Tanks While 'Despicable Me 2' Scores Huge | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2013/07/07/weekend-box-office-the-lone-ranger-tanks-while-despicable-me-2-scores-huge/| work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate= July 7, 2013|date=July 7, 2013}} After under-performing during its opening weekend, the film was characterized by numerous media sources as a box office [[box office bomb|flop]] with many observers comparing it unfavorably to [[John Carter (film)|''John Carter'']], another big-budgeted Disney film that failed commercially the year before.Scott Mendelson, [https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2013/07/07/weekend-box-office-the-lone-ranger-tanks-while-despicable-me-2-scores-huge/ Weekend Box Office: 'The Lone Ranger' Tanks While 'Despicable Me 2' Scores Huge], ''Forbes'', July 7, 2013, accessed July 8, 2013.Amy Kaufman, [http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-box-office-lone-ranger-despicable-me-20130707,0,30028.story No. 1 'Despicable Me 2' rules box office as 'Lone Ranger' flops], ''Los Angeles Times'', July 7, 2013, accessed July 8, 2013.Brooks Barnes, [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/08/movies/masked-lawman-stumbles-at-the-gate.html Masked Lawman Stumbles at the Gate], ''The New York Times'', July 8, 2013, accessed July 8, 2013.{{cite news|first=Andrew|last=Stewart|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/box-office/box-office-despicable-me-2-soars-with-142-mil-while-lone-ranger-stalls-with-less-than-50-mil-1200543853/|title=Box Office: ‘Despicable Me 2′ Soars With $142 Mil, While ‘Lone Ranger’ Stalls With Less Than $50 Mil|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date= July 7, 2013|accessdate=July 8, 2013}}{{cite news |first=Scott |last=Bowles |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2013/07/08/lone-ranger-flop-box-office/2497611/ |title='Lone Ranger' a wild misfire despite loot, star power |work=USA Today |date=July 8, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130922011620/https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2013/07/08/lone-ranger-flop-box-office/2497611/ |archivedate=September 22, 2013}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' estimated that the film cost $375 million to produce and market, and would need to earn an estimated $650 million worldwide to break even, after accounting for revenue splits with theater owners. ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' noted that the losses from the film could surpass $150 million, with [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures]] vice-president Dave Hollis calling these results "very disappointing".{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Disney's 'Lone Ranger' Could Lead to $150 Million Loss (Analysis)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disneys-lone-ranger-could-lead-581503|accessdate= July 8, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date= July 7, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Grady|title=Despite 'The Lone Ranger', Disney will press on with 'branded tentpole strategy'|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/07/10/lone-ranger-disney-tentpole-strategy/|accessdate=December 14, 2013|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=July 10, 2013}} Compared to ''[[Despicable Me 2]]'', a film that opened the same weekend to $142.1 million on a $76 million budget, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' noted that ''The Lone Ranger'' made just under a third of that ($48.9 million) and had more than three times the budget ($215 million). Nearly 68% of ticket buyers were over 25 years old and nearly 25% over 50 years old, a much higher percentage than is typical for the studio.{{cite news|first=Ben|last=Fritz|first2=Erich|last2= Schwartzel|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324867904578591893601731874|title='Lone Ranger' Trampled by 'Despicable Me 2'|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=July 7, 2013|accessdate=July 8, 2013}} Disney viewed the film's international performance ($24.3 million from 24 markets), including that of Russia and Australia, as "softer than we would have liked." ''The New York Times'' and ''[[USA Today]]'' reported that ''The Lone Ranger'' joined a string of high-concept western films that failed at the box office, such as 1999's ''[[Wild Wild West]]'', which cost $170 million but grossed $222 million, 2011's ''[[Cowboys & Aliens]]'', which cost $160 million but grossed $100 million and 2010's ''[[Jonah Hex (film)|Jonah Hex]]'', which cost $47 million but grossed less than $11 million. Chief analyst for [[Boxoffice (magazine)|''Boxoffice'']] Phil Contrino described the film's box office performance as "the kind of bomb that people discuss for years to come" due to its use of otherwise successful director, producer and stars. [[Alan Horn]], current [[Walt Disney Studios (production)|Walt Disney Studios]] chairman, admitted the financial risk the studio faced with the film.{{cite news|last=Masters|first=Kim|title=Disney's Alan Horn Talks 'Lone Ranger' Risks, Jerry Bruckheimer's Future (Q&A)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/alan-horn-lone-ranger-risks-577825|accessdate= July 8, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date= July 1, 2013}} [[Jay Rasulo]], [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] CFO, expects to attribute a loss of $160–190 million in the company's [[The Walt Disney Studios (production company)|Studio Entertainment]] division during the fourth [[fiscal quarter]].{{cite news|last=Shaw|first=Lucas|title='The Lone Ranger' to Cost Disney $160-$190M in Q4|url=http://www.thewrap.com/movies/article/lone-ranger-cost-disney-160-190m-q4-earnings-108876|accessdate=7 August 2013|newspaper=The Wrap|date= August 6, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Lieberman|first=David|title=Disney Expects To Write Down As Much As $190M For ‘Lone Ranger’|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/08/disney-expects-to-write-down-as-much-as-190m-for-lone-ranger/|accessdate= August 7, 2013|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date= August 6, 2013}} In September 2014, studio president Alan Bergman was asked at a conference if Disney had been able to partially recoup its losses on ''The Lone Ranger'' and ''John Carter'' through subsequent release windows or other monetization methods, and he responded: "I'm going to answer that question honestly and tell you no, it didn't get that much better. We did lose that much money on those movies."{{cite web|last1=Bergman|first1=Alan|title=Transcript: Bank of America Merrill Lynch 2014 Media and Entertainment Conference|url=http://cdn.media.ir.thewaltdisneycompany.com/2014/events/ab-baml-2014-0917.pdf|publisher=The Walt Disney Company|accessdate=10 November 2014|date=17 September 2014}} ===Critical response=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds an approval rating of 31% based on 229 reviews with an average rating of 4.8/10. The site's consensus reads, "Armie Hammer and Johnny Depp make for an appealing pair of leads, but they're not enough to make up for ''The Lone Ranger'''s bland script, bloated length, and blaring action overkill."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_lone_ranger/|title=The Lone Ranger (2013)|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]]|accessdate=8 March 2018}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 37 out of 100, based on reviews from 45 critics, indicating "generally unfavorable reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/lone-ranger|title=The Lone Ranger Reviews|website=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive|CBS Interactive Inc.]]|accessdate=2 July 2013}} [[Mick LaSalle]] of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' gave the film a negative review, calling the film "a jumbled botch that is so confused in its purpose and so charmless in its effect that it must be seen to be believed, but better yet, no. Don't see it, don't believe it."{{cite web|url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/entertainment/article/The-Lone-Ranger-review-Lawman-turns-antihero-4642814.php?t=9ee2720ae147b02379|title='The Lone Ranger' review: Lawman turns antihero|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|date=2 July 2013|accessdate=2 July 2013}} [[Lou Lumenick]] of the ''[[New York Post]]'' was equally scathing, calling it a "bloated, misshapen mess, a stillborn franchise loaded with metaphors for its feeble attempts to amuse, excite and entertain."{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/movies/groan_ranger_W9CKI1UgK8KByCLg3ykiuI|title=Stunts and effects can't bring 'The Lone Ranger' back to life|work=[[New York Post]]|date=2 July 2013|accessdate=2 July 2013|first=Lou|last=Lumenick}} Charlie McCollum of the ''[[San Jose Mercury News]]'' wrote, "In the end, ''The Lone Ranger'' is one hot mess—an entertaining one, to be sure, but still a mess."{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/entertainment/ci_23577434/review-lone-ranger-one-hot-mess |title=Review: 'The Lone Ranger,' one hot mess - San Jose Mercury News|publisher=Mercurynews.com|date=1 July 2013|accessdate=8 August 2013}} Tim Walker of ''[[The Independent]]'' gave a mixed review, praising Gore Verbinski for "employ[ing] the Old West to good effect, with gorgeous widescreen vistas that owe everything to [[Sergio Leone]] and [[John Ford]]." However, he added, "it takes a full hour for Reid to don his mask, and then there’s another 80 unremarkable minutes to go."{{cite news|first=Tim|last=Walker|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/first-night-the-lone-ranger-disney-studios-burbank-los-angeles-8686220.html|title=Review: Behind the mask is yet another forgettable Lone Ranger - Reviews - Films|publisher=The Independent|date=3 July 2013|accessdate=8 August 2013|location=London}} Among some of the positive reviews, James Verniere of the ''[[Boston Herald]]'' wrote, "The film, part spoof, part pastiche, is chockablock with violent incident, spectacular settings, [[Buster Keaton]]-esque action and colorful characters out of [[spaghetti Western]]s of yore."{{cite news|url=http://bostonherald.com/entertainment/movies/movie_reviews/2013/07/lone_ranger_takes_western_fans_on_wild_ride|title=‘Lone Ranger’ takes Western fans on wild ride|date=2 July 2013|first=James|last=Verniere|work=[[Boston Herald]]}} Andrew O'Hehir of [[Salon.com]] called it "an ambitious and inventive film that’s always trying to tweak formula and play with audience expectations. If anything, it’s overstuffed with imagination and ideas...."{{cite web|title="The Lone Ranger": Rip-roaring adventure meets dark political parable|first=Andrew|last=O'Hehir|work=[[Salon.com]]|date=2 July 2013|url=http://www.salon.com/2013/07/02/the_lone_ranger_rip_roaring_adventure_meets_dark_political_parable/|accessdate=3 July 2013}} Jon Niccum of the ''[[Kansas City Star]]'' stated, "The movie takes a more old-fashioned approach to thrills. It appears to showcase as many stuntmen as it does digital compositors."{{cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/2013/07/02/4324244/the-lone-ranger-johnny-depp-rides.html|title=‘The Lone Ranger’: Johnny Depp rides to the rescue|date=2 July 2013|first=Jon|last=Niccum|work=[[Kansas City Star]]}} Among British critics, the reception was more positive.{{cite news|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=135308|title='The Lone Ranger': Hi-Yo Fidelity|first=Angie|last=Errigo|work=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]|date=n.d.|accessdate=3 July 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/filmreviews/10171584/The-Lone-Ranger-review.html|title=The Lone Ranger, review|publisher=Telegraph|date=8 August 2013|accessdate=8 August 2013|location=London|first=Robbie|last=Collin}} Angie Errigo of the British film magazine ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' gave it four of five stars, finding "[r]eal storytelling, well thought-out and beautifully, at times insanely, executed, with excitement, laughs and fun to make you feel seven years old again." Robbie Collin of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' gave the film three stars out of five, writing, "Verbinski shows more ambition here than he did in ''Pirates of the Caribbean''." He added, "[I]n a sane world this would never have been made, although I’m really rather glad someone did." [[Frank Lovece]], writing for ''[[Film Journal International]]'', addressed critics' concerns over the film's tone by pointing out, "[T]he movie is told in flashback from the perspective of a wizened, quite eccentric character—the working definition of the film-school trope 'the unreliable narrator.' ... Whatever really happened out on the frontier, this is the story as Tonto remembers it, animist mysticism and all."{{cite news|url=http://www.filmjournal.com/filmjournal/content_display/reviews/major-releases/e3ib605acb6d713e0ac18ba32b8e7cba53b|title=Film Review: ''The Lone Ranger''|authorlink=Frank Lovece|first=Frank|last=Lovece|work=[[Film Journal International]]|date=2 July 2013|accessdate=3 July 2013}} [[Gore Verbinski]], [[Jerry Bruckheimer]], [[Armie Hammer]] and [[Johnny Depp]] openly criticized the American critical reception of the film, arguing that the negative coverage surrounding the project was influenced by reports of production troubles, with Bruckheimer accusing critics of "reviewing the budget," instead of the film itself.{{cite news|last=Parfitt|first=Orlando|title=Johnny Depp and Armie Hammer: Critics "slit the jugular" of The Lone Ranger (Exclusive)|url=http://uk.movies.yahoo.com/armie-hammer--critics-%E2%80%9Cslit-the-jugular%E2%80%9D-of-lone-ranger-141408705.html|accessdate=14 October 2013|publisher=[[Yahoo!|Yahoo! Movies UK]]|date=5 August 2013}} Hammer added, "If you go back and read the negative reviews, most of them aren't about the content of the movie, but more what's behind it. They tried to do the same thing to ''[[World War Z (film)|World War Z]]''; it didn't work, the movie was successful. Instead they decided to slit the jugular of our movie."{{cite news|last=Oldham|first=Stuart|title=Johnny Depp, Bruckheimer Blame Critics for ‘Lone Ranger’ Disaster | url = https://variety.com/2013/film/news/johnny-depp-bruckheimer-blame-critics-for-lone-ranger-failure-1200574397/|accessdate=14 October 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=5 August 2013}} Filmmaker [[Quentin Tarantino]] called the film one of the ten best films of 2013 through October:{{cite web|url=http://www.tarantino.info/2013/10/05/quentin-tarantinos-top-10-films-2013-far/|title=Quentin Tarantino’s Top 10 Films of 2013 – So Far|publisher=The Quentin Tarantino Archives|date=5 October 2013|accessdate=7 October 2013}} "The first forty-five minutes are excellent…the next forty-five minutes are a little soporific. It was a bad idea to split the bad guys in two groups; it takes hours to explain and nobody cares. Then comes the train scene—incredible! When I saw it, I kept thinking, ‘What, that’s the film that everybody says is crap? Seriously?’"{{cite web|last=Chitwood|first=Adam|url=http://collider.com/quentin-tarantino-lone-ranger-ben-affleck-batman/|title=Quentin Tarantino Elaborates on His Criticism of 'The Lone Ranger'; Comments on Ben Affleck as Batman|publisher=Collider|date=10 October 2013|accessdate=12 October 2013}} Film critic Scout Tafoya included the film in his video series "The Unloved" in 2015, likening the film's unfortunate circumstances to what the 1980 Western film ''[[Heaven's Gate (film)|Heaven's Gate]]'' similarly went through. Tafoya considers ''The Lone Ranger'' to be a masterpiece, praising the film's deconstruction of American myths which erased the tragedies experienced by Native Americans, stating: "There's a melancholy that runs through even the most frenetic, kinetic action sequence in ''The Lone Ranger''. No matter how big a grin it puts in your face, it's still about the deaths of thousands, not to mention our ideals, of the stain on our legacy as a united people."{{cite web|last1=Tafoya|first1=Scout|title=The Unloved - The Lone Ranger & Heaven's Gate|url=https://vimeo.com/120401922|website=[[Vimeo]]|publisher=Vimeo, Inc.|accessdate=29 January 2017|date=23 February 2015}}{{cite web|author1=[[Matt Zoller Seitz|Seitz, Matt Zoller]]|author2=Tafoya, Scout|title=The Unloved, Part Fifteen: "The Lone Ranger" & "Heaven's Gate"|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/mzs/the-unloved-part-fifteen-the-lone-ranger-and-heavens-gate|website=RogerEbert.com|publisher=Ebert Digital LLC|accessdate=29 January 2017|date=2 March 2015}} Film critic [[Matt Zoller Seitz]] of ''[[RogerEbert.com]]'' gave the film three-and-a-half out of four stars, stating that "for all its miscalculations, this is a personal picture, violent and sweet, clever and goofy. It's as obsessive and overbearing as [[Steven Spielberg]]'s ''[[1941 (film)|1941]]'' — and, I'll bet, as likely to be re-evaluated twenty years from now, and described as 'misunderstood.'"{{cite web|last1=Seitz|first1=Matt Zoller|title=The Lone Ranger Movie Review & Film Summary (2013)|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/the-lone-ranger-2013|website=RogerEbert.com|publisher=Ebert Digital LLC|accessdate=28 July 2016|date=3 July 2013}} ===Casting controversy=== Despite the producers citing the presence of an adviser from the Comanche Nation, some debated the advisability of casting of Depp as a Native American and whether the film would present a positive and accurate representation of the [[Comanche]].{{cite news|last=Fonseca|first=Felicia|title=Disney's Tonto Offensive To Some In Upcoming 'Lone Ranger' Film|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/12/disney-tonto-offensive-lone-ranger-film_n_3263071.html|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=22 June 2013|work=Huffington Post|date=12 May 2013}} Depp has stated he believes he has [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American ancestry]], possibly from a great-grandmother. He has said that he considered the role a personal attempt "to try to right the wrongs of the past", in reference to portrayals of Native American culture in the media.{{cite news|last=Thompson|first=Bob|title=Johnny Depp says he drew on his own native heritage to play The Lone Ranger’s Tonto|url=http://arts.nationalpost.com/2013/06/26/johnny-depp-says-he-drew-on-his-own-native-heritage-to-play-the-lone-rangers-tonto/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130628035514/http://arts.nationalpost.com/2013/06/26/johnny-depp-says-he-drew-on-his-own-native-heritage-to-play-the-lone-rangers-tonto/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=28 June 2013|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=[[National Post]]|location=[[Ontario]], Canada|date=16 June 2013}}{{cite news|title=Depp Trying to 'Right the Wrongs of the Past' With Tonto|url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2013/06/10/depp-trying-right-wrongs-past-tonto-149814|accessdate=27 June 2013|publisher=Indian County Today Media Network|date=10 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615073646/http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2013/06/10/depp-trying-right-wrongs-past-tonto-149814#|archive-date=2013-06-15|dead-url=yes|df=}} Todd McDaniels, a linguist at the [[Comanche Nation College]], commented on Depp's attempts to speak the [[Comanche language]], which has 25 to 30 living native speakers.{{Cite web|url=https://eng.ichacha.net/zaoju/comanche%20language.html|title="comanche language" in a sentence - comanche language sentence examples - ichacha.net sentence maker|website=eng.ichacha.net|access-date=2017-10-31}} "The words were there, the pronunciation was shaky, but adequate."McDaniels in {{Cite news|last=Peterson|first=Britt|title=In ‘The Lone Ranger,’ is Tonto really speaking Comanche?|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|accessdate=11 July 2013|date=6 July 2013|url=http://www.boston.com/2013/07/05/word-tonto/KjS0gKbgkdI6IBN9NhmeUL/story.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130710085545/http://www.boston.com/2013/07/05/word-tonto/KjS0gKbgkdI6IBN9NhmeUL/story.html|archivedate=10 July 2013|df=}} ===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%;" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! colspan="5" style="background: LightSteelBlue;" | Awards and nominations |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! Association ! Date of ceremony ! Category ! Nominee(s) ! Result |- | rowspan="2"|[[Academy Awards]] | rowspan="2"|[[86th Academy Awards|March 2, 2014]] | [[Academy Award for Best Makeup and Hairstyling|Best Makeup and Hairstyling]] |[[Joel Harlow]] and [[Gloria Pasqua-Casny]] | {{nominated}} |- | [[Academy Award for Best Visual Effects|Best Visual Effects]] |[[Tim Alexander (visual effects)|Tim Alexander]], [[Gary Brozenich]], [[Edson Williams]], and [[John Frazier]] | {{nominated}} |- | rowspan="5"| [[Golden Raspberry Awards]] | rowspan="5"| [[34th Golden Raspberry Awards|March 1, 2014]] | [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Picture|Worst Depp]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Screenplay|Worst Screenplay]] | [[Justin Haythe]], [[Ted Elliott (screenwriter)|Ted Elliott]] and [[Terry Rossio]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Prequel, Remake, Rip-off or Sequel|Worst Prequel, Remake, Rip-off or Sequel]] | | {{won}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards]]{{cite news|last=Ng|first=Philiana|title=Nickelodeon's Kids' Choice Awards Nominations Revealed|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/kids-choice-awards-2014-nominees-681858|accessdate=25 February 2014|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=24 February 2014}} | rowspan="2"| [[2014 Kids' Choice Awards|March 29, 2014]] | [[2014 Kids' Choice Awards#Favorite Male Buttkicker|Favorite Male Buttkicker]] | rowspan="2"| Johnny Depp | {{nom}} |- | [[2014 Kids' Choice Awards#Favorite Movie Actor|Favorite Movie Actor]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Saturn Awards]]{{cite news|last=Goldberg|first=Matt|url=http://collider.com/saturn-award-nominees-2014-gravity-hobbit-desolation-smaug/|title=Saturn Award Nominations Announced; GRAVITY and THE HOBBIT: THE DESOLATION OF SMAUG Lead with 8 Nominations Each|publisher=Collider|date=26 February 2014|accessdate=26 February 2014}}{{cite press release|publisher=Saturn Awards |title="Gravity" and "The Hobbit: The Desolation {{Infobox television | show_name = Trapped | image = Trapped (2001) Film Poster.jpg | image_alt = | caption = Film poster | genre = | creator = | based_on = | writer = Michael Vickerman | screenplay = | story = | director = [[Deran Sarafian]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[William McNamara]] * [[Parker Stevenson]] * [[Callum Keith Rennie]] * Suki Kaiser * [[Stefanie von Pfetten]] }} | narrated = | music = [[Bill Brown (composer)|Bill Brown]] | country = United States | language = English | num_episodes = | producer = Anthony Santa Croce | editor = Katina Zinner | cinematography = Jon Joffin | runtime = 90 minutes | company = Playa Inc.
Wilmark Entertainment | distributor = LK-TEL Vídeo
RTL Klub Televízió
Nelonen
e-m-s the DVD-Company | budget = | network = | released = {{start date|2001|7|24}} | website = }} '''''Trapped''''' is a [[2001 in film|2001]] [[television film]], written by Michael Vickerman and directed by Deran Sarafian. ==Plot== A group of guest must to escape a hotel that is on fire. ==Cast== * [[William McNamara]] as C. Whitmore Evans * [[Parker Stevenson]] as Oliver Sloan * [[Callum Keith Rennie]] as Anthony Bellio * Suki Kaiser as Susan Bellio * [[Stefanie von Pfetten]] as Rachel * [[Natassia Malthe]] as Marisa * [[Meat Loaf]] as Jim Hankins ==Reception== David Nusair from ''Reel Film Reviews'' gave ''Trapped'' only one star out of five, he stated: "Trapped doesn't really work, especially since we know exactly how these folks are going to get out of the burning building (c'mon, would it even be possible not to realize that Meat Loaf's ride is going to work its way back into the plot?) and the characters are straight out of a how-to-create-a-disaster-movie handbook. And for a flick with this many characters, remarkably few of them wind up charred corpses."{{cite web|last1=Nusair|first1=David|title=Mini Reviews (July 2002)|url=http://www.reelfilm.com/mini19.htm#trap|website=Reel Film Reviews|accessdate=24 May 2017}} Jules Faber from ''DVD.net'' gave the film 7 out of 10 stars, concluding: "Trapped is perhaps one of this new breed of film with some decent performances and clever, well-executed special effects. While a far cry from Oscar-winning portrayals, this is nonetheless a surprisingly good production, regardless of the rather tacked on ‘arsonist’ subplot."{{cite web|last1=Faber|first1=Jules|title=Trapped (2001)|url=http://www.dvd.net.au/review.cgi?review_id=3243|website=DVD.net|accessdate=24 May 2017}} On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], ''Trapped'' currently holds 60% of audience aprovation.{{cite web|title=Trapped (2001)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/trapped2001/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=24 May 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=tt0279480}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|id=trapped2001}} {{US-tv-film-stub}} [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Action films]]

revision.text:
A '''trío romántico''' is a group of [[vocal]]ists-[[guitar]]ists, with origins in [[Hispanic America]], that performs romantic songs, based on rhythms like [[bolero]], [[Vals Criollo|vals]] and [[pasillo]], mostly.
The ensemble may be composed of three musicians: first guitar, second guitar and [[requinto guitar]]. Sometimes it is accompanied by [[maracas]], or one of the guitars may be replaced by a [[double bass]], [[guitarron]] or [[Mexican vihuela]].
Among the renowned artists are [[Los Panchos]], Los Tres Ases, Los tres Reyes, and the singers [[Eydie Gormé]] and [[Lucho Gatica]].
== References == *[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-123707302.html bio] * [http://www.rtspecialties.com/onehundred/ Cien años de boleros] por Jaime Rico Salazar. * [http://historiatotal-dantesol.blogspot.com/2009/08/la-historia-del-bolero-latinoamericano.html Historia del Bolero ]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Trio Romantico}} [[Category:Latin American music]]
